image.altText: Ground crews in Tara are battling a number of fires.

items.synopsis: Emergency warnings are issued for Nymboida, Tabulam and Tenterfield in NSW, while dangerous fire conditions remain in south-western Queensland. Follow live.

title.children: Multiple emergency warnings issued for fires in NSW, while more than 50 homes are lost in Queensland blazes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk is addressing the situation in Tara now. She has 71 people are now in hotels after moving out of evacuation centres. "I think everyone is feeling absolutely heartbroken with what's been happening out there. "We have 71 people in hotels now, so that's great they're moving out of the evacuation centres."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland premier says 'everyone is feeling absolutely heartbroken' by Tara fires

children.content: Premier
Annastacia Palaszczuk is addressing the situation in Tara now.
She has 71 people are now in hotels after moving out of evacuation centres.
"I think everyone is feeling absolutely heartbroken with what's been happening out there.
"We have 71 people in hotels now, so that's great they're moving out of the evacuation centres."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says an evacuation centre has been set up at Childers. "One house has been damaged and as you know the school was evacuated earlier," she says. Authorities were previously concerned about Wallangarra, a border town between Queensland and NSW. Ms Palaszczuk says the "town has been saved". "The fire is now going around the town, so the town has been saved — this is tremendous work," she says. "I also want to thank the NSW government, because we utilised their large tanker, their large plane, and that has been of tremendous service."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One home has been damaged at Goodwood, but the town of Wallangarra 'has been saved'

children.content: Premier
Annastacia Palaszczuk says an evacuation centre has been set up at Childers.
"One house has been damaged and as you know the school was evacuated earlier," she says.
Authorities were previously concerned about Wallangarra, a border town between Queensland and NSW.
Ms Palaszczuk says the "town has been saved".
"The fire is now going around the town, so the town has been saved — this is tremendous work," she says.
"I also want to thank the NSW government, because we utilised their large tanker, their large plane, and that has been of tremendous service."

image.altText: A crowd of people stands around the wreckage of a burnt out building

title.children: More than 1.4 million displaced in Gaza as all 13 hospitals given evacuation orders, UN says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's hard to imagine what 200 – 300 kilometres of underground tunnels look and feel like. Hamas has spent years expanding its extensive underground warren of tunnels so that a second city thrives underneath the Gaza Strip. The stuffy, narrow passages can run low on oxygen, and at their deepest, the tunnels reach 70 metres below the Earth's surface. It's believed this is where Hamas leadership, fighters, headquarters, communication, weapons, and supplies like water, food and ammunition are hidden. More than 200 hostages kidnapped on October 7 are also trapped somewhere in this labyrinth, hoping for rescue. Dr Daphné Richemond-Barak, an expert on underground warfare who teaches at Reichman University in Israel, has been inside these tunnels from the Israel side (once they'd been cleared by the Israel Defense Forces of course). This is what she said it feels like to be down there: "When you go into these tunnels, they seem completely endless, and you don't even see the arteries on the side. "You might see a segment that comes on the right or an artery on the left, but once you're in it, it all looks very, very dark. And literally, you have no idea what is at the end of the tunnel. "It's claustrophobic and it's narrow, and you lose your sense of direction immediately. You lose complete sense of time. " Dr Richemond-Barak said she imagines the hostages are being held in one of the larger rooms built into the tunnel network: "Maybe there is some level of electricity, maybe they are being told what time it is, and what day it is. But if you don't have this information, you would lose track very quickly. "They are humid and suffocating and they are incredibly scary. So when you walk in them, you'd be disoriented for sure, but also incredibly afraid. "There's no way to determine in which direction you're walking. Have you crossed the border? Are you in a different country? The hostages are likely to feel exactly the same kind of feelings. The tunnels, they elicit this really kind of existential fear and you don't know how deep you are."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is it actually like in the Hamas tunnels?

children.content: It's hard to imagine what 200 – 300 kilometres of underground tunnels look and feel like. Hamas has spent years expanding its extensive underground warren of tunnels so that a second city thrives underneath the Gaza Strip.

The stuffy, narrow passages can run low on oxygen, and at their deepest, the tunnels reach 70 metres below the Earth's surface. It's believed this is where Hamas leadership, fighters, headquarters, communication, weapons, and supplies like water, food and ammunition are hidden. More than 200 hostages kidnapped on October 7 are also trapped somewhere in this labyrinth, hoping for rescue.

props.alt: A narrow underground tunnel with cement walls, and what appears to be dirt and scraps of material on the floor

children.content: A general view shows the interiors of what the Israeli military say is a cross-border attack tunnel dug from Gaza to Israel, in 2018.
(Reuters/Pool: Jack Guez)

Dr Daphné Richemond-Barak, an expert on underground warfare who teaches at Reichman University in Israel, has been inside these tunnels from the Israel side (once they'd been cleared by the Israel Defense Forces of course). This is what she said it feels like to be down there:
"When you go into these tunnels, they seem completely endless, and you don't even see the arteries on the side.
"You might see a segment that comes on the right or an artery on the left, but once you're in it, it all looks very, very dark. And literally, you have no idea what is at the end of the tunnel.
"It's claustrophobic and it's narrow, and you lose your sense of direction immediately. You lose complete sense of time. "
Dr Richemond-Barak said she imagines the hostages are being held in one of the larger rooms built into the tunnel network:
"Maybe there is some level of electricity, maybe they are being told what time it is, and what day it is. But if you don't have this information, you would lose track very quickly.
"They are humid and suffocating and they are incredibly scary. So when you walk in them, you'd be disoriented for sure, but also incredibly afraid.

"There's no way to determine in which direction you're walking. Have you crossed the border? Are you in a different country? The hostages are likely to feel exactly the same kind of feelings. The tunnels, they elicit this really kind of existential fear and you don't know how deep you are."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise — a "concept paper". The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site. In its report, the Intelligence Ministry — a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy — offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war". The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security. The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor. A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering. The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli ministry drafts plan to transfer Gaza civilians to Egypt

children.content: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise — a "concept paper".

props.alt: People walk through rubble in ruined streets.

children.content: (AP Photo: Abed Khaled)
The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site.

In its report, the Intelligence Ministry — a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy — offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war".
The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security.
The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor.
A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering.
The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities". "Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks. The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas. "So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel envoy wears yellow star at UN, accuses Security Council of 'staying silent'

children.content: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities".

props.alt: Gilad Erdan sits at a table wearing a yellow star of David reading "Never Again"

children.content: (AP Photo: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez )

"Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks.
The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas.
"So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said.
AFP
